metadata.purpose: ATLAS voice assistant exercise form library
metadata.personality: Lethal Gentleman - direct, efficient, no-nonsense coaching

context.equipment: Home gym - dumbbells, kettlebells, bench, resistance bands

goblet_squat.name: Goblet Squat
goblet_squat.setup: Hold weight at chest height with elbows tucked. Feet shoulder-width or slightly wider, toes turned out 15-30 degrees.
execution: Big breath into belly, brace core like you're about to get punched
Break at hips AND knees together - don't just push hips back
Push knees out in same direction as toes, don't let them cave
Lower until thighs parallel or just below - elbows between knees at bottom
Drive through whole foot to stand, squeeze glutes at top
cues: Spread the floor with your feet - creates hip tension
Proud chest, weight stays glued to sternum
Sit down between your legs, not back behind them
Think about pushing the floor away as you stand

common_mistakes.mistake: Weight shifts to toes / heels rise
common_mistakes.fix: Drive through whole foot. If mobility is the issue, elevate heels on a 1-inch plate or wedge.
Screw feet into floor, actively push knees out. Consider a resistance band above knees as a cue.

common_mistakes.mistake: Torso tips forward / lower back rounds
common_mistakes.fix: Keep chest up, elbows high. Weight acts as counterbalance - use it.

common_mistakes.mistake: Weight drifts forward away from body
common_mistakes.fix: Pin elbows to ribcage, keep weight at chest, not floating in front.

goblet_squat.breathing: Inhale at top, hold breath and brace during descent, exhale forcefully as you drive up

modifications.easier: Box squat - sit to a bench or box behind you for depth reference and confidence
modifications.harder: Pause 2-3 seconds at bottom, or add slow 4-second descent
modifications.ankle_friendly: Elevate heels 1-2 inches on plates or squat wedge - reduces ankle mobility demand

goblet_squat.phase1_notes: Perfect for Phase 1 - teaches squat mechanics with lighter load. Good for your ankle rehab since you can elevate heels if dorsiflexion is limited.

rdl.name: Romanian Deadlift
rdl.setup: Stand tall, feet hip-width, weights held at thighs. Slight bend in knees that STAYS FIXED throughout. Shoulders back, chest proud.
execution: Unlock knees slightly - this angle doesn't change during the lift
Initiate by pushing hips BACK, not by bending forward
Let weights slide down thighs - keep them close, they're not swinging out
Lower until you feel strong hamstring stretch - stop before back rounds
Drive hips forward to stand, squeeze glutes hard at top
cues: Imagine closing a car door with your arse
Hips back like someone's pulling you by a belt
Weights paint your thighs - never lose contact
Neutral spine is non-negotiable - stop when it wants to round
Hamstrings are springs - load them, then release

common_mistakes.mistake: Turning it into a squat - bending knees too much
common_mistakes.fix: Set slight knee bend at start and FREEZE it. The movement is a hip hinge, not a squat.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding lower back to get more range
common_mistakes.fix: Your range is determined by hamstring flexibility. Stop when spine wants to flex. Tightness beats depth.
Engage lats, pull weights into thighs. Think about bending the bar around your legs.
Neutral neck - look at floor 6 feet ahead. Chin tucked, not jutting.

rdl.breathing: Breath in at top, brace core, hold during descent, exhale as you drive hips forward

modifications.easier: Use blocks or plates as targets - tap them at bottom for feedback
modifications.harder: Slow 4-second descent, 2-second pause at bottom stretch
modifications.single_leg: Single-leg RDL for balance and asymmetry correction

rdl.phase1_notes: Essential hip hinge pattern. Use tempo to ingrain proper mechanics. Protects lower back by training posterior chain properly.

floor_press.name: Dumbbell Floor Press
floor_press.setup: Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat on floor. Dumbbells at chest height, elbows on floor at 45-degree angle to torso - NOT flared at 90 degrees.
execution: Squeeze shoulder blades together, press them into floor
Grip dumbbells tight, wrists neutral - not bent back
Press up and slightly in - weights meet above chest, not face
Lower with control until upper arms touch floor - don't bounce
Brief pause on floor, then press again
cues: 45-degree elbow angle - protects your shoulder
Drive shoulder blades into the floor
Squeeze glutes and brace core for stability
Control the descent - floor is not a trampoline
Think about pushing yourself away from the weights

common_mistakes.mistake: Elbows flared at 90 degrees to body
common_mistakes.fix: Tuck to 45 degrees. This is shoulder-safe pressing - critical with your rotator cuff.
Touch floor gently, pause, then press. The pause removes momentum - makes you stronger.
Squeeze glutes, press lower back toward floor. Core should be braced.
Stack wrist over elbow. Weight should sit on heel of palm, not fingers.

floor_press.breathing: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you press

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights, focus on slow negatives
modifications.harder: Pause 2 seconds with triceps on floor
modifications.shoulder_safe: Neutral grip (palms facing each other) reduces shoulder stress - USE THIS with your rotator cuff

floor_press.phase1_notes: Your primary pressing movement. Floor stops elbows from going too deep - protects your shoulder capsule. Use NEUTRAL GRIP given your rotator cuff situation.

chest_supported_row.name: Chest-Supported Dumbbell Row
chest_supported_row.setup: Set incline bench to 30-45 degrees. Lie face-down with chest on pad, feet planted on floor. Arms hang straight down, dumbbells in hands.
execution: Keep chest pressed firmly on bench throughout - no lifting
Initiate pull by driving ELBOWS back, not by yanking with hands
Row dumbbells toward lower ribs or hip crease
Squeeze shoulder blades together at top - hold for a beat
Lower with control, let shoulders protract slightly at bottom
cues: Elbows lead, hands follow - like a puppeteer pulling strings
Lead with elbows down and back, not out to sides
Squeeze a pencil between shoulder blades at top
Chest stays glued to bench - if it lifts, you're cheating
Think about putting elbows in your back pockets

common_mistakes.fix: Keep shoulders depressed. Think about pushing shoulders away from ears as you row.
Reduce weight. The point is isolating the back without momentum or lower back involvement.

common_mistakes.mistake: Elbows flaring straight out to sides
common_mistakes.fix: Angle elbows toward hips for lat emphasis, or 45 degrees for mid-back. Not straight out.
Slow and controlled. If you need momentum, the weight is too heavy.

chest_supported_row.breathing: Exhale as you row up, inhale as you lower

grip_variations.neutral: Palms facing each other - better lat stretch, easier on elbows
grip_variations.pronated: Palms down - more upper back and rear delt

modifications.easier: Lighter weight, higher bench angle (more vertical)
modifications.harder: Pause 2 seconds at top contraction, or slow 4-second lowering

chest_supported_row.phase1_notes: Perfect for your shoulder - takes load off rotator cuff while still training pulling strength. Zero lower back stress. Use neutral grip.

kb_clean_press.name: Kettlebell Clean and Press
kb_clean_press.setup: Stand with feet hip-width, KB between feet. Hinge to grab handle with one hand, thumb pointing back.
execution: CLEAN: Hike KB back, snap hips forward, guide KB to rack position
In rack: elbow tucked to ribs, KB rests on forearm and bicep, wrist neutral
Pause and reset - don't rush into press
PRESS: Brace hard, slight lat engagement, press KB overhead
Lock out with bicep by ear, KB stacked over shoulder
Lower KB to rack, then back to start position

clean: Thumb to bum on the backswing
Zip up a jacket - KB travels close to body, not out in a loop
Let hand rotate AROUND the bell, not under it
Soft landing in rack - bell doesn't slap forearm
press: Root feet into ground, squeeze glutes, brace core
Crush the handle to create tension
Press up and slightly back - lock out behind ear, not in front of face

common_mistakes.fix: Keep KB close, rotate hand around it. Think of inserting your hand into a glove. Use lighter weight until smooth.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using arms to muscle the clean up
common_mistakes.fix: Power comes from HIPS. Arms are just guides. If arms are sore, you're not using hips.
Squeeze glutes HARD, brace abs. If you need to lean back, the weight is too heavy.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rushing from clean straight into press
common_mistakes.fix: Pause in rack. Reset. Breathe. Then press. Two distinct movements.

kb_clean_press.breathing: Sharp exhale on hip snap for clean. Fresh breath in rack. Exhale on press.

modifications.easier: Practice clean and press as separate movements first
modifications.shoulder_safe: Keep elbow slightly forward during press - don't let it drift behind body
modifications.progression: Dead clean (from floor each rep) → Hang clean → Full clean

kb_clean_press.phase1_notes: Complex movement - master the clean before adding the press. With your shoulder, focus on neutral pressing path. Stop if any sharp pain. This builds explosive power and conditioning.

plank.name: Plank
plank.setup: Forearms on floor, elbows directly under shoulders. Extend legs, rest on toes. Body forms straight line from head to heels.
execution: Squeeze glutes like you're holding a coin between your cheeks
Brace core - imagine someone's about to punch your stomach
Push forearms into floor, don't sink between shoulder blades
Tuck pelvis slightly - don't let lower back sag or pike up
Maintain tension through ENTIRE body - this is not passive holding
cues: Could someone eat dinner off your back? That flat.
Squeeze everything - abs, glutes, quads, fists
Long spine - reach crown of head forward, heels back
Belly button to spine
Breathe! Don't hold your breath - steady inhales and exhales

common_mistakes.fix: Engage glutes, tuck pelvis, pull belly button to spine. If you can't maintain, drop to knees.

common_mistakes.mistake: Hips piked up (butt in the air)
common_mistakes.fix: You're making it easier. Lower hips until body is straight. Engage core harder.
Breathe normally. Steady rhythm. Core should stay braced regardless of breathing.
Push forearms into floor, engage lats. Imagine you're pushing the floor away.

plank.breathing: Steady controlled breathing throughout - don't hold breath

modifications.harder: Single arm or single leg plank

duration_guidelines.advanced: Focus on harder variations rather than longer holds - quality over quantity

plank.phase1_notes: Foundation core exercise. Perfect form for 30 seconds beats sloppy form for 2 minutes. Progress by adding difficulty (variations) not just time.

face_pull.name: Face Pull
face_pull.setup: Band anchored at face height. Step back until tension in band. Grab with thumbs pointing BACK (not overhand grip).
execution: Start with arms extended, shoulders protracted forward slightly
Pull toward face, splitting hands apart as you pull
Elbows stay at shoulder height or slightly below - not flared up
External rotate at top - thumbs end up pointing behind you
Squeeze shoulder blades, hold for a beat, control back to start
cues: Thumbs back grip - creates external rotation which is the whole point
Pull apart as you pull back - think of trying to snap the band
Elbows at shoulder height, not rising up toward ears
Finish position looks like a double bicep pose
Don't shrug - keep shoulders away from ears

common_mistakes.fix: Thumbs pointing back. Overhand causes internal rotation under load - bad for shoulders.
Keep elbows at shoulder level or slightly below. High elbows cause impingement.
The external rotation IS the exercise. Pull hands apart at the end, thumbs rotate back.
Slow and controlled. This is a rehab/prehab movement, not an ego lift.

face_pull.breathing: Exhale as you pull, inhale as you return

modifications.banded: Loop band around pull-up bar or sturdy anchor at face height
modifications.seated: Sit on floor with band around feet for home setup
modifications.with_external_rotation: After pulling to face, rotate hands up and back (like a scarecrow)

face_pull.phase1_notes: CRITICAL for your shoulder rehab. Do these every session. They train the muscles that are weak in most people and essential for shoulder health. Light weight, high reps, perfect form.

rep_ranges.frequency: Every training day - before pressing work

side_lying_external_rotation.name: Side-Lying External Rotation
side_lying_external_rotation.setup: Lie on side, bottom arm under head for support. Top elbow bent 90 degrees, pinned to side. Small towel roll under elbow optional for comfort.
execution: Keep elbow glued to your side throughout - it doesn't move
Rotate forearm up toward ceiling, keeping elbow at 90 degrees
Go until forearm is vertical or you feel stretch - don't force range
SLOW eccentric - lower over 4 seconds (this is where the magic happens)
Brief pause at bottom, then lift again
cues: Elbow is a hinge - only forearm moves, upper arm stays still
Shoulder blade stays back and down - don't let it roll forward
Control the lowering - gravity wants to drop it, you resist
Think about the back of your shoulder doing the work
If you feel it in front of shoulder or down arm, check position

common_mistakes.fix: Pin a small towel between elbow and ribs. If it falls, elbow moved.

common_mistakes.mistake: Body rolls backward to get more range
common_mistakes.fix: Stay stacked on your side. Range of motion is limited by your mobility - that's fine.
1-2 kg max. These are small muscles. Heavy weight shifts load to bigger muscles.
Slow, especially the lowering. 4 seconds down minimum. Quality over quantity.

side_lying_external_rotation.breathing: Exhale as you rotate up, inhale during slow lowering

modifications.progression: Start bodyweight, add 0.5-1kg when 15 reps feels easy
modifications.emphasis: Eccentric focus - 4 second lowering builds tendon strength

side_lying_external_rotation.phase1_notes: THE key exercise for your supraspinatus rehab. Do these EVERY session. Eccentric loading is what repairs tendon tissue. Never go heavy. Never rush. This is medicine.

rep_ranges.frequency: Daily during rehab phase, or every training day minimum

farmer_walk.name: Farmer's Walk
farmer_walk.setup: Dumbbells on floor at sides. Deadlift them up with proper form. Stand tall, shoulders back, weights at sides.
execution: Stand tall - crown of head reaching to ceiling
Shoulders back and down - don't let weights pull you forward
Grip hard - squeeze the handles like you're trying to crush them
Core braced - like wearing a weightlifting belt
Walk with controlled, deliberate steps - no rushing
When done, lower weights with a controlled deadlift, not a drop
cues: Walk like you own the place - tall, proud, controlled
Death grip on the handles - this IS grip training
Keep weights from swinging - body stays rigid
Short, quick steps - not long strides
Eyes forward, chin neutral - don't look down at feet

common_mistakes.fix: Pull shoulder blades back and down. Think about putting them in back pockets.
If uneven, one side is weaker. Use equal weight but pay attention to weak side.
Controlled steps. Speed is not the point. Time under tension is.
Lower with deadlift form. Eccentric loading is valuable. Control the entire movement.

farmer_walk.breathing: Steady breathing throughout - don't hold breath for long carries

modifications.suitcase_carry: One weight only - massive core anti-rotation challenge
modifications.overhead_carry: Weight held overhead - shoulder stability (not with your current shoulder)
modifications.lighter_longer: Lighter weights, more distance = conditioning focus
modifications.heavier_shorter: Heavier weights, shorter distance = strength focus

farmer_walk.phase1_notes: Functional full-body exercise. Builds grip that transfers to all other lifts. Core stability without spinal loading. Great conditioning tool.

split_squat.name: Split Squat
split_squat.setup: Staggered stance - front foot flat on ground, back foot behind (on floor for regular, elevated on bench for Bulgarian). Front knee roughly over ankle at bottom.
execution: 80-90% of weight goes through front foot - back leg is just balance
Lower straight down - don't lunge forward
Front knee tracks over toes - don't let it cave inward
Back knee lowers toward floor (don't slam it)
Drive up through front heel, squeeze glute at top
cues: Elevator, not escalator - straight down and up
Front heel stays planted - if it rises, stance is too narrow
Back leg is a kickstand, not a driver
Torso stays upright - don't tip forward
90 degrees at both knees at bottom is the goal

common_mistakes.mistake: Too much weight on back leg
common_mistakes.fix: Front leg should burn, not back leg. Shift weight forward.
Push knee out over pinky toe. Weak glute med - do banded work.
Step further back. At bottom, front shin should be roughly vertical.
Stance too short. Foot further from bench. Or ankle mobility issue - work on it.

split_squat.breathing: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you drive up

modifications.regular_split_squat: Back foot on floor - easier balance, good starting point
modifications.bulgarian: Back foot elevated on bench - harder, more quad/glute focus
modifications.deficit: Front foot elevated on plate - increases range of motion
modifications.goblet_hold: Weight at chest for counterbalance and core activation

split_squat.phase1_notes: Great unilateral work - finds and fixes imbalances. Start with regular split squats, progress to Bulgarian when stable. Front foot positioning matters for ankle comfort.

deadlift.name: Deadlift
deadlift.setup: Feet hip-width, weights beside feet. Hinge hips back, bend knees to grab weights. Chest proud, shoulders over or slightly in front of weights. Neutral spine.
execution: Brace core HARD - like bracing for a punch
Push the floor away with your feet - don't think 'pull'
Weights stay close to body throughout - don't let them drift forward
Hips and shoulders rise together - don't let hips shoot up first
Stand tall at top - squeeze glutes, don't hyperextend lower back
Reverse the motion to lower - hips back, controlled descent
cues: Push the floor away through your heels
Big chest, long arms - don't round shoulders
Bar/weights travel in a straight line up
Squeeze oranges in your armpits - engages lats
Stand tall and proud at top - no excessive leaning back

common_mistakes.fix: Don't go lower than you can with neutral spine. Brace harder. If it rounds, stop and reset.

common_mistakes.mistake: Hips shoot up, back becomes horizontal
common_mistakes.fix: Push through heels, drive hips forward. Think about humping the bar, not rowing it.
Engage lats, keep weights in contact with legs. Paint your shins with the bar.
Neutral neck. Look at floor 6 feet ahead at bottom, horizon at top.

deadlift.breathing: Big breath at top, brace, hold during lift, exhale at top, controlled lowering

modifications.trap_bar: More quad-dominant, easier to keep neutral spine - great choice for Phase 1
modifications.dumbbell: Weights beside feet - similar pattern, home gym friendly
modifications.elevated: Plates under weights to reduce range - if mobility is limited
modifications.romanian: Start from standing, less knee bend - more hamstring focus (separate entry)

deadlift.phase1_notes: Trap bar or dumbbell deadlifts are your friend in Phase 1. More forgiving on form, still build the pattern. Focus on the hip hinge mechanics.

single_leg_balance.name: Single Leg Balance
single_leg_balance.setup: Stand tall on one leg. Other knee lifted to hip height. Arms wherever helps balance (out to sides, hands on hips, or crossed).
execution: Stand on one leg - foot pointing straight ahead
Slight bend in standing knee - not locked out
Engage core, squeeze glute of standing leg
Hold position - minimize wobbling
Eyes forward on fixed point for easier balance
cues: Root through whole foot - tripod stance (heel, big toe, little toe)
Standing knee tracks over toes
Hip stays level - don't let it drop on lifted side
Tall spine - crown of head reaching up
Breathe normally - don't hold breath

common_mistakes.fix: Slight bend. Locked knee reduces proprioceptive feedback and stresses joint.

common_mistakes.mistake: Hip drops on lifted leg side
common_mistakes.fix: Engage glute med on standing leg. Think about keeping pelvis level.

common_mistakes.mistake: Weight shifts to edge of foot
common_mistakes.fix: Spread through whole foot. If rolling out, glute med is weak. If rolling in, control through big toe.
Normal breathing. Your core should brace without requiring breath hold.

progression.eyes_open_unstable: Pillow, foam pad, or wobble cushion

single_leg_balance.phase1_notes: GATE 1 REQUIREMENT: 60 seconds eyes open, 30 seconds eyes closed. Essential for ankle rehab. Train daily - it's skill work, not strength work.

heel_raises.name: Single Leg Heel Raises
heel_raises.setup: Stand on one leg, ball of foot on edge of step (optional), other foot lifted. Hand on wall or rail for light balance support only.
execution: Push through ball of foot to raise heel as high as possible
Pause at top - full contraction
Lower slowly with control (3-4 seconds)
Go below step level if using step (full stretch)
Use hand for balance only - not to push yourself up
cues: Push up through big toe, not rolling to outside of foot
Straight ankle - don't let it wobble side to side
Full range of motion - bottom to top
Control the eccentric - lowering builds strength
Hand is for balance, not assistance

common_mistakes.fix: Light fingertip touch only. The calf does the work.
Rise onto tiptoes - full plantar flexion. Partial reps = partial results.
Control the lowering - this eccentric portion is crucial for tendon health.
Keep ankle neutral. If unstable, don't use step yet - do flat ground first.

heel_raises.breathing: Exhale as you rise, inhale as you lower

modifications.easier: Both feet, or flat ground instead of step
modifications.progression: Flat ground → Step with full range → Add hold at top → Add slow eccentric

heel_raises.phase1_notes: GATE 1 REQUIREMENT: 25 reps each leg, LSI ≥90% (limb symmetry index - injured leg must be at least 90% of healthy leg). Critical for ankle return to sport.

quick_reference.shoulder_safe_pressing: Neutral grip floor press with 45-degree elbow angle
quick_reference.ankle_mobility_help: Elevate heels for goblet squats and split squats if dorsiflexion limited

voice_response_format.medium: {name}. {setup} Execution: {execution[0:3]}. Key cues: {cues[0:3]}. Common mistake: {common_mistakes[0].mistake} - fix: {common_mistakes[0].fix}
voice_response_format.full: Return all fields formatted for voice
